member.name: M:IVINET.Internal.Core.SetAttribute(IVINET.Internal.RCItemCollection,IVINET.Internal.OptionFlags,System.Int64,System.Object)
member.summary:
Purpose: This function sets the ViInt32, ViInt64, ViReal64, ViBoolean and ViString attribute you specify to a new value. Depending on the configuration of the attribute, the function performs the following actions:
Checks whether the attribute is writable. If not, the function returns an error. Validates the value you specify if RS_ATTR_RANGE_CHECK is enabled for the session. If you provide a check callback, the function invokes the callback to validate the value. If you do not provide a check callback but you provide a range table or a range table callback, the function invokes the default RS check callback to validate the value. If the value is invalid, the function returns an error. Coerces the value you specify into a canonical value the instrument accepts. If you provide a coerce callback, the function invokes the callback to coerce the value. If you do not provide a coerce callback but you provide a coerced range table directly or through a range table callback, the function invokes the default RS coerce callback to coerce the value. Compares the new value with the current cache value for the attribute to see if they are equal. When the cache value is a value the RS Library obtained by querying the instrument and you provide a compare callback for the attribute, the function invokes the compare callback. Otherwise, the function makes the comparison based on strict equality. If the new value is not equal to the cache value or the cache value is invalid, the function invokes the write callback for the attribute. The write callback might perform I/O to send the value to the instrument. The RS Library stores the new value in the cache. If the function coerces the value, the function caches the coerced value rather than the value you pass. If the RS_VAL_WAIT_FOR_OPC_AFTER_WRITES flag is set for the attribute, the function invokes the operation complete (OPC) callback you provide for the session. If you set the RS_VAL_DIRECT_USER_CALL bit in the Option Flags parameter, the RS_ATTR_QUERY_INSTR_STATUS attribute is enabled, and the RS_VAL_DONT_CHECK_STATUS flag for the attribute is 0, then the function invokes the check status callback you provide for the session.
Note: If you set the RS_VAL_SET_CACHE_ONLY bit in the Option Flags parameter, or if the simulate flag attribute is enabled and the RS_VAL_USE_CALLBACKS_FOR_SIMULATION flag for the attribute is 0, the function does not call the write callback, the operation complete callback, or the check status callback. It merely updates the cache value of the attribute.

member.name: M:IVINET.Internal.Core.GetAttribute(IVINET.Internal.RCItemCollection,IVINET.Internal.OptionFlags,System.Int64,System.Object@)
member.summary:
Purpose: This function obtains the current value of the ViInt32, ViReal64, ViBoolean and ViString attribute you specify.
If the attribute you specify is type of ViString, you must provide a ViChar array to serve as a buffer for the value. You pass the number of bytes in the buffer as the Buffer Size parameter. If the current value of the attribute, including the terminating NUL byte, is larger than the size you indicate in the Buffer Size parameter, the function copies Buffer Size - 1 bytes into the buffer, places an ASCII NUL byte at the end of the buffer, and returns the buffer size you must pass to get the entire value. For example, if the value is "123456" and the Buffer Size is 4, the function places "123" into the buffer and returns 7. If you want the function to fill in the buffer regardless of the number of bytes in the value, pass a negative number for the Buffer Size parameter. If you want to call this function just to get the required buffer size, you can pass 0 for the Buffer Size and NULL for the Attribute Value buffer. Remember that the checkErr and viCheckErr macros ignore positive return values. If you use one of these macros around a call to this function, you lose the required buffer size when the function returns it. To retain this information, declare a separate local variable to store the required buffer size, and use the macro around the assignment of the return value to the local variable.
The following is an example:
ViStatus error = VI_SUCCESS; ViInt32 requiredBufferSize;
checkErr( requiredBufferSize = Rs_GetAttribute (vi, channel, attr, 0, 0, NULL));
Depending on the configuration of the attribute, the function performs the following actions:
Checks whether the attribute is readable. If not, the function returns an error. If the attribute cache value is currently valid, the read callback for the attribute is NULL, or the simulate flag is enabled and the RS_ATTR_USE_CALLBACKS_FOR_SIMULATION flag for the attribute is 0, the function returns the cache value. If the RS_VAL_WAIT_FOR_OPC_BEFORE_READS flag is set for the attribute, the function invokes the operation complete (OPC) callback you provide for the session. The function invokes the read callback for the attribute. Typically, the callback performs instrument I/O to obtain a new value. The RS Library stores the new value in the cache. If you set the RS_VAL_DIRECT_USER_CALL bit in the Option Flags parameter, the RS_ATTR_QUERY_INSTR_STATUS attribute is enabled, and the RS_VAL_DONT_CHECK_STATUS flag for the attribute is 0, then the function invokes the check status callback you provide for the session.

member.summary: This function sets the flags of an attribute to new values. It always sets all of the flags. If you want to change one flag, use Rs_GetAttributeFlags to obtain the current values of all the flags, modify the bit for the flag you want to change, and then call Rs_SetAttributeFlags. You cannot modify the value of the RS_VAL_MULTI_CHANNEL flag.

member.name: M:IVINET.Internal.Core.CheckStatusCallback
member.summary:
Purpose: This function queries the instrument to determine if it has encountered an error. If the instrument has encountered an error, this function returns the RS_ERROR_INSTRUMENT_SPECIFIC error code. This function is called by the Rs_CheckStatus utility function. The Rs_SetAttribute and Rs_GetAttribute functions invoke this function when the optionFlags parameter includes the RS_VAL_DIRECT_USER_CALL flag.
The user can disable calls to this function by setting the RSCMW_QUERY_INSTRUMENT_STATUS attribute to VI_FALSE. The driver can disable the check status callback for a particular attribute by setting the RS_VAL_DONT_CHECK_STATUS flag.

member.name: M:IVINET.Internal.Core.ResetAttributeCache
member.summary: Resets attributes' cache

member.name: M:IVINET.Internal.Core.CheckStatus
member.summary: Purpose: This function checks the status of the instrument to detect whether the instrument has encountered an error. This function is called at the end of most exported driver functions. If the instrument reports an error, this function returns RS_ERROR_INSTRUMENT_SPECIFIC. The user can set the rscmw_ATTR_QUERY_INSTRUMENT_STATUS attribute to VI_FALSE to disable this check and increase execution speed.

member.name: T:IVINET.Internal.STB
member.summary: Status flags

member.name: F:IVINET.Internal.STB.None
member.summary: None

member.name: F:IVINET.Internal.STB.Empty0
member.summary: Not used

member.name: F:IVINET.Internal.STB.Empty1
member.summary: Not used

member.name: F:IVINET.Internal.STB.ERROR
member.summary: Error Queue not empty The bit is set when an entry is made in the error queue. If this bit is enabled by the SRE, each entry of the error queue generates a service request. Thus an error can be recognized and specified in greater detail by polling the error queue. The poll provides an informative error message. This procedure is to be recommended since it considerably reduces the problems involved with remote control.

member.name: F:IVINET.Internal.STB.QUES
member.summary: Questionable status sum bit The bit is set if an EVENt bit is set in the QUEStionable: status register and the associated ENABle bit is set to 1. A set bit indicates a questionable instrument status, which can be specified in greater detail by polling the QUEStionable status register

member.name: F:IVINET.Internal.STB.MAV
member.summary: MAV bit (message available) The bit is set if a message is available in the output buffer which can be read. This bit can be used to enable data to be automatically read from the instrument to the controller.

member.name: F:IVINET.Internal.STB.ESB
member.summary: ESB bit Sum bit of the event status register. It is set if one of the bits in the event status register is set and enabled in the event status enable register. Setting of this bit indicates a serious error which can be specified in greater detail by polling the event status register.

member.name: F:IVINET.Internal.STB.MSS
member.summary: MSS bit (master status summary bit) The bit is set if the instrument triggers a service request. This is the case if one of the other bits of this registers is set together with its mask bit in the service request enable register SRE.

member.name: T:IVINET.Internal.ESR
member.summary: Error state register flags

member.name: F:IVINET.Internal.ESR.None
member.summary: None

member.name: F:IVINET.Internal.ESR.OPC
member.summary:
Operation Complete
This bit is set on receipt of the command *OPC exactly when all previous commands have been executed.

member.name: F:IVINET.Internal.ESR.Empy1
member.summary: Not used

member.name: F:IVINET.Internal.ESR.QE
member.summary:
Query Error
This bit is set if either the controller wants to read data from the instrument without having sent a query, or if it does not fetch requested data and sends new instructions to the instrument instead. The cause is often a query which is faulty and hence cannot be executed.

member.name: F:IVINET.Internal.ESR.DDE
member.summary:
Device-dependent Error
This bit is set if a device-dependent error occurs. An error message with a number between -300 and -399 or a positive error number, which denotes the error in greater detail, is entered into the error queue.

member.name: F:IVINET.Internal.ESR.EE
member.summary:
Execution Error
This bit is set if a received command is syntactically correct but cannot be performed for other reasons. An error message with a number between -200 and -300, which denotes the error in greater detail, is entered into the error queue.

member.name: F:IVINET.Internal.ESR.CE
member.summary:
Command Error
This bit is set if a command is received, which is undefined or syntactically incorrect. An error message with a number between -100 and -200, which denotes the error in greater detail, is entered into the error queue.

member.name: F:IVINET.Internal.ESR.UR
member.summary:
User Request
This bit is set on pressing the Local softkey.

member.name: F:IVINET.Internal.ESR.PO
member.summary:
Power On (supply voltage on)
This bit is set on switching on the instrument.

member.name: T:RohdeSchwarz.RsScope.IRsScopeTriggerRunt
member.summary: A runt is a pulse lower than normal in amplitude. The amplitude crosses the first threshold twice in succession without crossing the second one. In addition to the threshold amplitudes, you can define a time limit for the runt in the same way as for width triggers. For example, this trigger can detect logic, digital, and analog signals remaining below a specified threshold amplitude because I/O ports are in undefined state. Implemented repeated capability (use as named index) Trigger (TrigA, TrigB, TrigR)

summary.para: Defines the time limit of the runt pulse in relation to the TRIGger<m>:
RUNT: WIDTh and TRIGger<m>: RUNT: DELTa settings.
Defines the upper or lower voltage threshold.
Defines a range around the runt width specified using TRIGger<m>: RUNT:
WIDTh. This attribute is only available if TRIGger<m>: RUNT: RANGe is set
Defines the polarity of a pulse, that is the direction of the first pulse slope.

member.name: T:RohdeSchwarz.RsScope.IRsScopeTriggerGlitch
member.summary: The glitch trigger event detects pulses shorter or longer than a specified time. It identifies deviation from the nominal data rate and helps to analyze causes of even rare glitches and their effects on other signals. Implemented repeated capability (use as named index) Trigger (TrigA, TrigB, TrigR)

summary.para: Sets the length of a glitch. The instrument triggers on pulses shorter or longer
Defines the polarity of a pulse, that is the direction of the first pulse slope.
Selects which glitches are identified: shorter or longer than the width.

member.name: T:RohdeSchwarz.RsScope.IRsScopeTriggerWidth
member.summary: Attributes that configure the oscilloscope for width triggering. You use these attributes to configure the oscilloscope after you set the RSSCOPE_ATTR_TRIGGER_TYPE to RSSCOPE_VAL_WIDTH_TRIGGER. A width trigger occurs when the oscilloscope detects a positive or negative pulse with a width between, or optionally outside, the width thresholds. The trigger occurs when the edge of a pulse that corresponds to the width thresholds, width condition, and polarity you specify crosses the trigger level you specify with the RSSCOPE_ATTR_TRIGGER_LEVEL attribute. Implemented repeated capability (use as named index) Trigger (TrigA, TrigB, TrigR)

summary.para: Sets how the measured pulse width is compared with the given limit(s).
For the ranges 'Within' and 'Outside', the width defines the center of a range
which is defined by the limits '+/-Delta'. For the ranges 'Shorter' and
'Longer', the width defines the maximum and minimum pulse width, respectively.
Defines a range around the width value.
Sets the polarity of the pulse.

member.name: T:RohdeSchwarz.RsScope.IRsScopeTriggerWindow
member.summary: The window trigger checks the signal run in relation to a 'window'. The window is formed by the upper and lower voltage levels. The event condition is fulfilled, if the waveform enters or leaves the window, or if the waveform stays inside or outside for a time longer or shorter than specified. With the window trigger, you can display longer transient effects. Implemented repeated capability (use as named index) Trigger (TrigA, TrigB, TrigR)

summary.para: Defines the signal run in relation to the window.
For the ranges 'Within' and 'Outside', the width defines the center of a time
range which is defined by the limits 'Delta'.
For the ranges 'Shorter' and 'Longer', it defines the maximum and minimum time
Defines a range around the 'Width' value.
Selects how the time limit of the window is defined. Time conditioning is
available for the vertical conditions 'Stay within' and 'Stay outside'.

member.name: T:RohdeSchwarz.RsScope.IRsScopeWindowTriggerSource
member.summary: Selects Trigger Source Implemented repeated capability (use as named index) TriggerSource (TsCH1, TsCH2, TsCH3, TsCH4, TsExt, TsLine) Trigger (TrigA, TrigB, TrigR)

summary.para: Sets the upper voltage limit for the window.
Sets the lower voltage limit for the window.

member.name: T:RohdeSchwarz.RsScope.IRsScopeTriggerTimeout
member.summary: The timeout trigger event checks if the signal stays above or below the threshold voltage for a specified time lapse. In other words, the event occurs if the trigger source does not have the expected transition within the specified time. Implemented repeated capability (use as named index) Trigger (TrigA, TrigB, TrigR)

summary.para: Defines the relation of the signal level to the trigger level.
Defines the time limit for the timeout at which the instrument triggers.

member.name: T:RohdeSchwarz.RsScope.IRsScopeTriggerInterval
member.summary: The interval trigger analyzes the time between two pulses. While the interval trigger can only analyze either positive or negative polarity, searching for an interval is also possible for both polarities at the same time ('Either'). Implemented repeated capability (use as named index) Trigger (TrigA, TrigB, TrigR)

summary.para: Defines the range of an interval in relation to the interval width.
Defines the time between two pulses.
Defines a range around the 'Interval width' value.
Sets the edge for the trigger. You can analyze the interval between positive

member.name: T:RohdeSchwarz.RsScope.IRsScopeTriggerSlewRate
member.summary:
The slew rate trigger, also known as transition trigger, can detect fast or slow edges selectively. It triggers on edges, if the transition time from the lower to higher voltage level (or vice versa) is shorter or longer as defined, or outside a specified time range. The trigger event finds slew rates faster than expected or permissible to avoid overshooting and other interfering effects. It also detects very slow edges violating the timing in pulse series.
The slew rate trigger is not available for the B-event (Suffix = 2). Implemented repeated capability (use as named index) Trigger (TrigA, TrigB, TrigR)

summary.para: Defines the time limit for the slew rate in relation to the upper or lower
trigger level. The time measurement starts when the signal crosses the first
trigger level - the upper or lower level depending on the selected slope - and
stops when the signal crosses the second level.
For the ranges 'Within' and 'Outside', the slew rate defines the center of a
range which is defined by the limits 'Delta'.
For the ranges 'Shorter' and 'Longer', the slew rate defines the maximum and
minimum slew rate limits, respectively. When the signal crosses this level, the
slew rate measurement starts or stops depending on the selected slope.
Defines a time range around the slew rate.
Selects the edge type for the trigger event.

member.name: T:RohdeSchwarz.RsScope.IRsScopeSlewRateTriggerSource
member.summary: Selects Trigger Source Implemented repeated capability (use as named index) TriggerSource (TsCH1, TsCH2, TsCH3, TsCH4, TsExt, TsLine) Trigger (TrigA, TrigB, TrigR)

summary.para: Defines the upper voltage threshold. When the signal crosses this level, the
slew rate measurement starts or stops depending on the selected slope.
Defines the lower voltage threshold. When the signal crosses this level, the
slew rate measurement starts or stops depending on the selected slope.

member.name: T:RohdeSchwarz.RsScope.IRsScopeTriggerData2Clock
member.summary:
With the Data2Clock event - also known as setup/hold - you can analyze the relative timing between two signals: a data signal and the synchronous clock signal. Many systems require, that the data signal must be steady for some time before and after the clock edge, for example, the data transmission on parallel interfaces. With this trigger type, you can also test the time correlation of sideband and inband signals. The event occurs if the data signal crosses the data level during the setup and hold time. The reference point for the time measurement is defined by clock level and clock edge.
The Data2Clock trigger is only available for the A-event (Suffix = 1). Implemented repeated capability (use as named index) Trigger (TrigA, TrigB, TrigR)

summary.para: Selects the input channel of the clock signal.
Sets the voltage level for the clock signal. Both this command and
TRIGger<m>:DATatoclock:CSOurce:EDGE define the starting point for
calculation of the setup and hold time.
Sets the minimum time after the clock edge while the data signal must stay
steady above or below the data level. The hold time can be negative. In this
case, the setup time is always positive. The setup/hold interval starts before
the clock edge (setup time) and ends before the clock edge (hold time). If you
change the negative hold time, the setup time is adjusted by the intrument.
Sets the minimum time before the clock edge while the data signal must stay
steady above or below the data level. The setup time can be negative. In this
case, the hold time is always positive. The setup/hold interval starts after the
clock edge (setup time) and ends after the clock edge (hold time). If you change
the negative setup time, the hold time is adjusted by the intrument.
Sets the edge of the clock signal to define the time reference point for the

member.name: T:RohdeSchwarz.RsScope.IRsScopeTriggerPattern
member.summary:
The pattern trigger is a logic trigger. It provides logical combinations of the input channels and supports you in verifying the operation of digital logic. The setup of the pattern trigger is very similar to trigger qualification. In addition to the pattern and the trigger levels, you can define a timing condition.
The pattern trigger is only available for the A-event (Suffix = 1). Implemented repeated capability (use as named index) Trigger (TrigA, TrigB, TrigR)

summary.para: Adds additional time limitation to the pattern definition.
Defines the condition for the timeout.
Defines how long the result of the pattern condition must be true or false.
Defines how the range of a pulse width is defined for keeping up the true result
For the ranges 'Within' and 'Outside', the width defines the center of a range
which is defined by the limits 'Delta'.
For the ranges 'Shorter' and 'Longer', the width defines the maximum and minimum
Defines a time range around the width value.

member.name: T:RohdeSchwarz.RsScope.IRsScopeTriggerSerialPattern
member.summary:
The serial pattern event is used to trigger on signals with serial data patterns in relation to a clock signal - for example, on bus signals like the I2C bus. For convenient and comprehensive triggering on specific serial data, options for serial protocol analysis are provided.
The serial pattern trigger is only available for the A-event (Suffix = 1). Implemented repeated capability (use as named index) Trigger (TrigA, TrigB, TrigR)

Defines the voltage level for the clock signal.
The pattern contains the bits of the serial data to be found in the data stream.
The maximum length of the pattern is 128 bit. You can enter the pattern in
Together with the clock level, the clock edge defines the point in time when the
state of the data signal is checked.

member.name: T:RohdeSchwarz.RsScope.IRsScopeTriggerQualification2
member.summary:
By qualifying a trigger event, you can logically combine the trigger signal with the state of other digital channel signals. The instrument triggers if both of the following apply: - The basic conditions of the trigger event definition are fulfilled. - The logical conditions of the trigger qualification are true.
Qualification is not supported with slew rate, Data2Clock, and serial pattern trigger types.
The A-event and B-event in a trigger sequence can have their own trigger qualification. Qualification is not available for R-events (Suffix m = 3).
Example: Trigger on write access of a specific device of a bus system In circuits using SPI, several slave devices use the same lines for reading and writing data, and each slave has its own select line. To trigger on write access of specific slave, the write line is the trigger source and the select line of the slave is set as qualifiying. Implemented repeated capability (use as named index) TriggerType (Edge, Width, Runt, Glitch, Window, Timeout, Interval, Slew, Data2Clock, Pattern, External, T11, T12, NFC, TV, CDR) Trigger (TrigA, TrigB, TrigR)

summary.para: Enables the use of the qualification definition for the selected trigger event.

member.name: T:RohdeSchwarz.RsScope.IRsScopeTriggerSequence
member.summary: A trigger sequence consists of at least one trigger event and additional conditions defining when the trigger occurs. The simple sequence 'A only' contains an A-event and the holdoff setting as optional condition. The complex trigger sequence 'A › B › R' consists of two events - A and B - and an optional reset condition. After the A-event conditions have been met, the B-event with independent conditions is enabled. A- and B-events are configured in the same way. Without any reset, the instrument waits until one or a specified number of B-events occurs that causes the trigger, and then the sequence starts again. If you expect, for example, an irregular B-trigger event, you can configure a reset condition to restart the sequence with the A-event. The reset condition can be a simple timeout, or a trigger event that is defined in the same way as the A- and B-trigger events. The instrument checks the trigger settings for compatibility and disables settings that do not fit the previous settings in the sequence. Implemented repeated capability (use as named index) Trigger (TrigA, TrigB, TrigR)

summary.para: Selects the type of the sequence.
Selects the method to define the holdoff condition. The trigger holdoff defines
when the next trigger after the current will be recognized. Thus, it affects the
next trigger to occur after the current one. Holdoff helps to obtain stable
triggering when the oscilloscope is triggering on undesired events.
Defines the holdoff time period. The next trigger occurs only after this time
has passed. The setting is relevant if the holdoff mode is set to TIME.
Defines the number of triggers to be skipped. The next trigger only occurs when
this number of events is reached. The setting is relevant if the holdoff mode is
Defines the lower limit for the random time holdoff. The setting is relevant if
the holdoff mode is set to RANDom.
Defines the lower limit for the random time holdoff. The setting is relevant if
the holdoff mode is set to RANDom.
Returns the resulting holdoff time if the holdoff mode is set to AUTO: Auto time
Sets the auto time scaling factor the horizontal scale is multipied with: Auto
time = Auto time scaling * Horizontal scale. The setting is relevant if the
holdoff mode is set to AUTO.
Sets the time the instrument waits after an A-event until it recognizes
Sets the number of B-events to be fulfilled after an A-event. The last B-event
If set to ON, the instrument waits for the time defined using
TRIGger<m>:SEQuence:RESet:TIMeout:TIME for the specified number of
B-events. If no trigger occurs during that time, the sequence is restarted with
The time the instrument waits for the number of B-events specified using
TRIGger<m>:SEQuence:COUNt before the sequence is restarted with the
If set to ON, the trigger sequence is restarted by the R-event if the specified
number of B-event does not occur.

member.name: T:RohdeSchwarz.RsScope.IRsScopeCursors
member.summary: Cursor measurements determine the results at the current cursor positions. The cursors can be positioned manually or can be configured to follow the peaks of the waveform. Up to four sets of cursors can be configured and displayed. Each set of cursors consists of a pair of horizontal or vertical cursors, or both. Cursors can be coupled so that the initially defined distance is always maintained. Implemented repeated capability (use as named index) Cursor (C1, C2, C3, C4)

summary.para: Switches the indicated cursor on or off.
Defines the source of the cursor measurement.
If set to ON, the horizontal cursor lines follow the waveform.
Defines the positioning mode of the vertical cursor.
ON: Moving one cursor line moves the other cursor line too. The cursor lines
OFF: Each cursor line is positioned independently.
Defines the positioning mode of the horizontal cursor. If the horizontal cursor
lines track the waveform, the y-coupling is irrelevant.
ON: Moving one cursor line moves the other cursor line too. The cursor lines
OFF: Each cursor line is positioned independently.
If the waveform arithmetics are set to envelope curve and cursor tracking is set
to 'ON', this setting defines how the first horizontal cursor is positioned.
If the waveform arithmetics are set to envelope curve and cursor tracking is set
to 'ON', this setting defines how the second horizontal cursor is positioned.
Queries the delta value (distance) of the two horizontal cursor lines.
Queries the delta value (distance) of two vertical cursor lines.
Queries the inverse value of the delta value (distance) of the two vertical
Defines the minimum level by which the waveform must rise or fall so that it
will be identified as a maximum or a minimum by the search functions.
Defines an absolute threshold as an additional condition for the peak search.
Only peaks that exceed the threshold are detected.
If enabled, the second corsor lines Cx.2 measure on the second source. Using a
second source, you can measure differences between two channels with cursors.
Shows the cursor labels in the diagram.
Defines how the cursor is displayed in the diagram.

member.name: T:RohdeSchwarz.RsScope.IRsScopeMeasurementsHistograms
member.summary: Histograms are used to plot density of data, i.e. to display graphically how often which signal values occur. In the R&S RTO, the histogram can be based on the input signal levels (amplitudes) or the time base in a time domain measurement, or on frequencies or frequency levels in a spectrum measurement. Depending on which data the histogram is based on, a vertical or horizontal histogram can be selected. A vertical, or amplitude, histogram displays horizontal bars across amplitude values. A horizontal or time/frequency histogram displays vertical bars over time/frequencies. Implemented repeated capability (use as named index) Measurement (M1, M2, M3, M4, M5, M6, M7, M8, M9, M10)

summary.para: Defines or queries the main measurement. This measurement is the one referred to
if the measurement waveform is used as a source for math calculations. The main
measurement type must belong to the same category as the other types assigned to
the same measurement waveform, if there are any.
Selects the histogram on which the measurement is based.
Defines the marker reference in the probability domain.
Defines a range around the probability marker.

member.name: T:RohdeSchwarz.RsScope.IRsScopeMathematicsFFT
member.summary: Attributes for setting FFT parameters. During FFT analysis, a signal in the time domain is converted to a spectrum of frequencies. A basic FFT waveform can be displayed very quickly. By defining additional FFT parameters, the waveform can be configured in more detail. As a result, either the magnitude or the phase of the determined frequencies can be displayed, or more complex FFT functions. Analysis can be restricted to an extract of the original time base, and the results display can be restricted to a specified frequency range. Implemented repeated capability (use as named index) Math (M1, M2, M3, M4)

The arithmetic mode defines how the final FFT result is calculated from the
Restricts the maximum number of frames to be calculated. Due to the other
parameter settings, the required number of frames may become very high, thus
slowing performance. By restricting the number of frames, you can avoid
performance loss without changing the other parameters.
Due to the restriction of the number of frames, the waveform may only be
analyzed partially. This attribute queries the percentage of the trace that was
analyzed, i.e. which part of the trace was included in the frame calculation.
Defines the minimum factor by which two neighboring frames overlap. If the
required number of frames to cover the input values allows for more overlap, the
The higher the overlap factor, the more frames are used. This leads to more
individual results and improves detection of transient signal effects. However,
it also extends the duration of the calculation.

member.name: T:RohdeSchwarz.RsScope.IRsScopeMaskTesting
member.summary: Masks are used to determine whether the signal remains within specified limits, e.g. to uncover signal anomalies or test compliance and stability of digital signals. The limits are specified as 'mask', which is laid over the input signal in the display. Thus you can easily detect where the signal violates the mask. Mask testing with R&S RTO has only a minor impact on the acquisition rate, thus mask violations are detected very fast and reliably. With R&S RTO, you can define own masks easily. Specific actions can be executed when mask violations occur. For error analysis, you can stop the acquisition on a failed test and use the history view to look at the previous waveforms.

summary.para: This attribute selects the mask name used for following attributes.

member.name: T:RohdeSchwarz.RsScope.IRsScopeMaskDefinitionUser
member.summary: A user mask is defined by entering the time and voltage values for all corner points of the mask segments. A user mask has at least one segment. Complex masks can have up to 16 segments. An inner segment is an area defined by three or more points. Upper and lower segments limit the signal on top and bottom of the screen. They are defined by a line, the region above or below the line is set automatically as mask segment.

summary.para: Sets the segment that is in use.
This attribute returns the number of segments in the mask definition.

member.name: T:RohdeSchwarz.RsScope.IRsScopeMaskDefinitionWaveform
member.summary: A waveform mask is created from an existing waveform. The waveform builds the upper and lower limit line of the mask, and the limits are moved and stretched. The result is a tolerance tube around the waveform that is used as mask.

summary.para: Sets the reference waveform from which the mask is created.
Sets the width of the mask in horizontal direction. The specified number of
divisions is added to the positive x-values and subtracted from the negative
x-values of the mask limits in relation to the source waveform of the mask. The
overall mask width is twice the specified horizontal width.
Sets the width of the waveform mask in vertical direction. The specified number
of divisions is added to the y-values of the upper mask limit and subtracted
from the y-values of the lower mask limit. Thus, the upper half of the mask is
pulled upwards, the lower half is pulled down, and the overall height of the
mask is twice the vertical width.
This control sets the vertical scaling to stretch the mask in y-direction. The
scaling axis is the horizontal line through the lowest value of the lower mask
This attribute moves the mask vertically within the display.

member.name: T:RohdeSchwarz.RsScope.IRsScopeSearch
member.summary: Search functions allow you to detect and analyze specific conditions in the acquired data quickly and simply. This is possible both for running acquisitions or for waveforms stored in the sample memory, or for an extract of either. Various search conditions are available, including trigger parameters such as edges, windows or states. Search results can then be qualified further by other waveform conditions.

summary.para: This attribute selects the search name used for following attributes.
Defines the source on which the search conditions are applied. The source can be
any analog or digital channel, math or reference waveform.
If enabled, a search is performed repeatedly for each new data acquisition.
Creates a new search definition with the specified name.
Performs a single search for the next result on the existing data from the
Performs a search for all results on the existing data from the selected source.
Clears the search results once to start a new search.
Sets the trigger level automatically to 0.5 * (MaxPeak MinPeak). The attribute
is not available for an external trigger source.

member.name: T:RohdeSchwarz.RsScope.IRsScopeSearchTrigger
member.summary: For trigger searches, most parameters available for trigger event definition can also be configured as search conditions. However, not only signal channels, but also math and reference waveforms can be selected as the search source. Each event type is defined in a separate tab. You can enable several event types for simultaneous search.

summary.para: Sets the voltage level for the trigger level that is used to determine other
This attribute returns the trigger search condition. It provides logical
combinations of the input channels, math or reference waveforms, and supports
you in verifying the operation of digital logic.
Copies the trigger event configuration from Trigger A for the selected channel
source to the search condition settings.
Copies the trigger event configuration from Trigger B for the selected channel
source to the search condition settings.

member.name: T:RohdeSchwarz.RsScope.IRsScopeEdge
member.summary: Configures the conditions for the edge trigger search. An edge trigger occurs when the trigger signal passes through the voltage threshold that you specify with the Trigger Level parameter and has the slope that you specify with the Trigger Slope parameter.

summary.para: Includes the search conditions for the edge trigger event type in the next

member.name: T:RohdeSchwarz.RsScope.IRsScopeSearchTriggerGlitch
member.summary: Configures the conditions for the glitch trigger search. A glitch trigger occurs when the trigger signal has a pulse with a width that is less than the glitch width. You specify the glitch width in the Glitch Width parameter. You specify the polarity of the pulse with the Glitch Polarity parameter. The trigger does not actually occur until the edge of a pulse that corresponds to the Glitch Width and Glitch Polarity crosses the threshold you specify in the Trigger Level parameter.

summary.para: Includes the search conditions for the glitch trigger event type in the next
Sets the length of a glitch. The instrument triggers on pulses shorter or longer
Defines the polarity of a pulse, that is the direction of the first pulse slope.
Selects which glitches are identified: shorter or longer than the specified

member.name: T:RohdeSchwarz.RsScope.IRsScopeSearchTriggerWidth
member.summary: Configures the conditions for the width trigger search. A width trigger occurs when the oscilloscope detects a positive or negative pulse with a width between, or optionally outside, the width thresholds. You specify the width thresholds with the Width Low Threshold and Width High Threshold parameters. You specify whether the oscilloscope triggers on pulse widths that are within or outside the width thresholds with the Width Condition parameter. You specify the polarity of the pulse with the Width Polarity parameter. The trigger does not actually occur until the edge of a pulse that corresponds to the Width Low Threshold, Width High Threshold, Width Condition, and Width Polarity crosses the threshold you specify in the Trigger Level parameter.

summary.para: Includes the search conditions for the width trigger event type in the next
For the ranges 'Within' and 'Outside', the width defines the center of a range
which is defined by the limits '+/-Delta'. For the ranges 'Shorter' and
'Longer', the width defines the maximum and minimum pulse width, respectively.
fines a range around the width value.
Sets the polarity of the pulse.
Sets how the measured pulse width is compared with the given limit(s).

member.name: T:RohdeSchwarz.RsScope.IRsScopeSearchTriggerRunt
member.summary: This class configures the conditions for the runt trigger search. A runt trigger occurs when the trigger signal crosses one of the runt thresholds twice without crossing the other runt threshold. You specify the runt thresholds with the Runt Low Threshold and Runt High Threshold parameters. You specify the polarity of the runt with the Runt Polarity parameter.

summary.para: Includes the search conditions for the runt trigger event type in the next
Defines the polarity of a pulse, that is the direction of the first pulse slope.

For the ranges 'Within' and 'Outside', the runt width defines the center of a
Defines a range around the runt width specified using Runt Width.
Selects how the time limit of the runt pulse is defined based on the runt width

member.name: T:RohdeSchwarz.RsScope.IRsScopeSearchTriggerWindow
member.summary: This class configures the conditions for the window trigger search. The window trigger checks the signal run in relation to a 'window'. The window is formed by the upper and lower voltage levels. The event condition is fulfilled, if the waveform enters or leaves the window, or if the waveform stays inside or outside for a time longer or shorter than specified. With the window trigger, you can display longer transient effects.

summary.para: Includes the search conditions for the window trigger event type in the next
Defines the signal run in relation to the window.
Selects how the time limit of the window is defined. Time conditioning is
available for the vertical conditions 'WITHin' and 'OUTSide'.
For the ranges 'Shorter' and 'Longer', the runt width defines the maximum and
For the ranges 'Within' and 'Outside', the runt width defines the center of a
Defines a range around the width value.

member.name: T:RohdeSchwarz.RsScope.IRsScopeSearchTriggerTimeout
member.summary: This class configures the conditions for the timeout trigger search. The timeout trigger event checks if the signal stays above or below the threshold voltage for a specified time lapse. In other words, the event occurs if the trigger source does not have the expected transition within the specified time.

summary.para: Includes the search conditions for the timeout trigger event type in the next
Defines the time limit for the timeout at which the instrument triggers.
Defines the relation of the signal level to the trigger level.

member.name: T:RohdeSchwarz.RsScope.IRsScopeSearchTriggerInterval
member.summary: This class configures the conditions for the interval trigger search. The interval trigger analyzes the time between two pulses. While the interval trigger can only analyze either positive or negative polarity, searching for an interval is also possible for both polarities at the same time ('Either').

summary.para: Includes the search conditions for the interval trigger event type in the next
Defines the time between two pulses
Defines a range around the 'Interval width' value.
Sets the polarity of the pulse.
Defines the range of an interval in relation to the interval width.

member.name: T:RohdeSchwarz.RsScope.IRsScopeSearchTriggerSlewRate
member.summary: This class configures the conditions for the slew rate trigger search. The slew rate trigger, also known as transition trigger, can detect fast or slow edges selectively. It triggers on edges, if the transition time from the lower to higher voltage level (or vice versa) is shorter or longer as defined, or outside a specified time range. The trigger event finds slew rates faster than expected or permissible to avoid overshooting and other interfering effects. It also detects very slow edges violating the timing in pulse series.

summary.para: Includes the search conditions for the slew rate trigger event type in the next
For the ranges 'Within' and 'Outside', the slew rate defines the center of a
range which is defined by the limits 'Delta'.
For the ranges 'Shorter' and 'Longer', the slew rate defines the maximum and
minimum slew rate limits, respectively. When the signal crosses this level, the
slew rate measurement starts or stops depending on the selected slope.
Defines a range around the 'Interval width' value.
Defines the polarity of a pulse, that is the direction of the first pulse slope.
Selects how the time limit for the slew rate is defined. The time measurement
starts when the signal crosses the first trigger level - the upper or lower
level depending on the selected slope - and stops when the signal crosses the

member.name: T:RohdeSchwarz.RsScope.IRsScopeSearchTriggerData2Clock
member.summary: This class configures the conditions for the data 2 clock trigger search. With the Data2Clock event - also known as setup/hold - you can analyze the relative timing between two signals: a data signal and the synchronous clock signal. Many systems require, that the data signal must be steady for some time before and after the clock edge, for example, the data transmission on parallel interfaces. With this trigger type, you can also test the time correlation of sideband and inband signals. The event occurs if the data signal crosses the data level during the setup and hold time. The reference point for the time measurement is defined by clock level and clock edge.

summary.para: Includes the search conditions for the data2clock trigger event type in the next
Selects the waveform used for the clock signal.
Sets the voltage level for the clock signal.
Sets the minimum time after the clock edge while the data signal must stay
steady above or below the data level. The hold time can be negative. In this
case, the setup time is always positive. The setup/hold interval starts before
the clock edge (setup time) and ends before the clock edge (hold time). If you
change the negative hold time, the setup time is adjusted by the intrument.
Sets the minimum time before the clock edge while the data signal must stay
steady above or below the data level. The setup time can be negative. In this
case, the hold time is always positive. The setup/hold interval starts after the
clock edge (setup time) and ends after the clock edge (hold time). If you change
the negative setup time, the hold time is adjusted by the intrument.
Sets the edge of the clock signal to define the time reference point for the

member.name: T:RohdeSchwarz.RsScope.IRsScopeSearchTriggerStateQualification
member.summary:
By qualifying a trigger event, you can logically combine the trigger signal with the state of other digital channel signals. The instrument triggers if both of the following apply: - The basic conditions of the trigger event definition are fulfilled. - The logical conditions of the trigger qualification are true.
Qualification is not supported with slew rate, Data2Clock, and serial pattern trigger types.
The A-event and B-event in a trigger sequence can have their own trigger qualification. Qualification is not available for R-events (Suffix m = 3).
Example: Trigger on write access of a specific device of a bus system In circuits using SPI, several slave devices use the same lines for reading and writing data, and each slave has its own select line. To trigger on write access of specific slave, the write line is the trigger source and the select line of the slave is set as qualifiying.

Returns the Start Code (= start of frame code) in the present acquisition of the
selected word and the selected serial bus. The parameter value '[bin]00'
represents Clause 45, while '[bin]01' stands for Clause 22.
Note that the values '[bin]10' and '[bin]11' do not correspond with any legal
parameters according to the standard, but they can still be searched for.
Returns the OpCode (= operation code or frame type) in the present acquisition
of the selected word and the selected serial bus.
Note that the user interface shows interpretations of the numerical OpCode
values corresponding to Clause 45: '0' (= [bin]00) represents Address, '1' (=
represents Read. Clause 22 is not represented by this interpretation.
Returns the 5-bit address field content (PHYAD/PRTAD) in the present acquisition
of the selected word and the selected serial bus.
Returns the 5-bit register or device address field content (REGAD/DEVAD) in the
present acquisition of the selected word and the selected serial bus.
Returns the 16-bit payload data field content (in Clause 22 or Clause 45), or
the 16-bit address field content (in Clause 45, only) in the present acquisition
of the selected word and the selected serial bus. The most significant bit (MSB)
Returns a textual translation (called Register Name) of the PHY or port address
label in the present acquisition of the selected word and the selected serial

member.name: T:RohdeSchwarz.RsScope.IRsScopeSearchEbTb
member.summary: The 8b/10b (Option R&S RTO-K52) coding scheme is used for high-speed serial data transmission, used by different standards, like fibre channel, PCIe, DVI and USB 3.0. Also the MIPI UniPro M-PHY interface in smartphones as well as display interfaces such as HDMI use 8b/10b encoding, as do base stations based on the Common Public Radio Interface (CPRI).

member.summary: Selects Time Segment Implemented repeated capability (use as named index) CANTimeSeg (TS1, TS2) SerialBus (SB1, SB2, SB3, SB4)

summary.para: Set the number of time quanta before the sample point (T1Segment) and after the
sample point (T2Segment). T1Segment comprises the segments Synch_seg, Prop_seg,
and Phase_seg1 which are specified in the CAN standard. T2Segment matches
Phase_seg2 specified in the CAN standard.
Note: The maximum sum of Time segment 1 and Time segment 2 is 24.
Set the number of time quanta before the sample point (T1Segment) and after the
sample point (T2Segment). T1Segment comprises the segments Synch_seg, Prop_seg,
and Phase_seg1 which are specified in the CAN standard. T2Segment matches
Phase_seg2 specified in the CAN standard.
Note: The maximum sum of Time segment 1 and Time segment 2 is 24.

member.name: T:RohdeSchwarz.RsScope.IRsScopeProtocolsFlexRay
member.summary:
FlexRay is designed for use in safety-related distributed applications in the automotive industry. It is applied in real-time applications when higher data rates and reliable communication are required. In particular, FlexRay supports x-by-wire applications, e.g. steer-by-wire or brake-by-wire.
Attributes in this class requires option R&S RTO-K3. Implemented repeated capability (use as named index) SerialBus (SB1, SB2, SB3, SB4)

type. The setting affects the digitization of the signal.

Sets the thresholds for the bus signal if the source type is Single or
This attribute selecs a default threshold voltage.
Sets the threshold for the data line if the source type is LOGic.
Sets the threshold for the enable line if the source type is LOGic.
Selects the channel on which the signal is measured. The setting is considered
in the calculation of the frame CRC.
Affects the decoding and its display. If ON, the leading five indicator bits of
the header are decoded as five single bits. Otherwise, the indicator bits are
shown as one word with word length five bit.
Queries the number of decoded frames.
Queries the number of the current FlexRay cycle.
Returns the overall state of the frame.

Return the stop time of the selected frame.
Returns the frame type of the selected frame.
Returns the value of the indicator bits at the beginning of the header segment.
The five bits are read as one word.
Returns the payload length, the number of data words in the payload segment.
Information is transmitted in 2-byte words, so the number of data bytes in the
payload segment is twice the payload length.

Returns the cyclic redundancy check code of the frame CRC.

Return the stop time of the selected word.
Returns the Start Code (= start of frame code) in the present acquisition of the
selected word and the selected serial bus. The parameter value '[bin]00'
represents Clause 45, while '[bin]01' stands for Clause 22.
Note that the values '[bin]10' and '[bin]11' do not correspond with any legal
parameters according to the standard, but they can still be searched for.
Returns the OpCode (= operation code or frame type) in the present acquisition
of the selected word and the selected serial bus.
Note that the user interface shows interpretations of the numerical OpCode
values corresponding to Clause 45: '0' (= [bin]00) represents Address, '1' (=
represents Read. Clause 22 is not represented by this interpretation.
Returns the 5-bit address field content (PHYAD/PRTAD) in the present acquisition
of the selected word and the selected serial bus.
Returns the 5-bit register or device address field content (REGAD/DEVAD) in the
present acquisition of the selected word and the selected serial bus.
Returns the 16-bit payload data field content (in Clause 22 or Clause 45), or
the 16-bit address field content (in Clause 45, only) in the present acquisition
of the selected word and the selected serial bus. The most significant bit (MSB)
Returns a textual translation (called Register Name) of the PHY or port address
label in the present acquisition of the selected word and the selected serial

member.name: T:RohdeSchwarz.RsScope.IRsScopeProtocolsCXPI
member.summary: Main characteristics of CXPI are: Carrier Sense Multiple Access (CSMA) and Collision Resolution (CR). The master sends pulse width modulated clock (PWMC). Support of the sleep/wake function to reduce power consumption. Support of two methods for frame transfer management, the event trigger method and the polling method. The event trigger method can be used when the focus is placed on the responsiveness of the slave node communication. The polling method puts the focus on the communication periodicity. Maximum baud rate of 20kbit/s. Up to 16 nodes connected to a communication bus Implemented repeated capability (use as named index) SerialBus (SB1, SB2, SB3, SB4)

member.name: T:RohdeSchwarz.RsScope.IRsScopeProtocolsPCIeCDR
member.summary: The process of clock data recovery (CDR) generates a reference clock from a highspeed serial data stream that is sent without a dedicated clock signal. The generated clock signal matches the frequency and is aligned to the phase of the data stream. The recovered clock can be used to sample the data stream and to obtain the sequence of transmitted bits. Implemented repeated capability (use as named index) SerialBus (SB1, SB2, SB3, SB4)

summary.para: Sets the quiescent frequency of the PLL. It corresponds to the data rate of the
data stream from which the clock is to be recovered.
Sets the order of the PLL: first or second order. PLL of higher order can
compensate for more complex jitter behavior.
Sets the PLL bandwidth. It defines the part of the spectrum that the PLL can
follow during synchronization. The PLL bandwidth is usually defined by the
Sets the PLL bandwidth. It defines the part of the spectrum that the PLL can
follow during synchronization. The PLL bandwidth is usually defined by the
Sets the damping factor, which is only relevant for second order PLL.
Defines the phase reference for the first clock edge.
The PLL requires some time to synchronize to the phase of the data stream. You
can select when the CDR algorithm returns clock edges.

member.name: T:RohdeSchwarz.RsScope.IRsScopeProtocolsMSO
member.summary: The Mixed Signal Option R&S RTO-B1 adds logic analyzer functions to the classical oscilloscope functions. Using the MSO option, you can analyze and debug embedded systems with mixed-signal designs that use analog signals and correlated digital signals simultaneously.

member.summary: MSO trigger settings.

member.name: T:RohdeSchwarz.RsScope.IRsScopeMSOTriggerEdge
member.summary: MSO trigger edge settings.

summary.para: Defines a logical combination of several digital channels as trigger condition.
Defines the edge - the state transition - of the signal to trigger on a single
digital channel (a logic bit), or a logical combination of digital channels.

member.name: T:RohdeSchwarz.RsScope.IRsScopeMSOTriggerWidth
member.summary: MSO trigger width settings.

summary.para: Defines a logical combination of several digital channels as trigger condition.
Sets the polarity of the pulse. When triggering on a positive pulse, the trigger
event occurs on the high to low transition of the pulse if the timing condition
is true. When triggering on a negative pulse, the trigger event occurs on the
low to high transition of the pulse if the timing condition is true.
Selects how the range of a pulse width is defined.
For the ranges 'Within' and 'Outside', the width defines the center of a range
which is defined by the limits '+/-Delta'. For the ranges 'Shorter' and
'Longer', the width defines the maximum and minimum pulse width, respectively.
Defines a range around the width value.

member.name: T:RohdeSchwarz.RsScope.IRsScopeGenerator
member.summary: The R&S RTO includes an integrated waveform generator which can generate input signals and patterns during testing. You can setup and output two waveform generators and a pattern generator. It is possible to couple and synchronize the settings of the different generators and enable them on a trigger signal. With each of the waveform generators, one can output simple functions, modulated sine waveform, arbitrary waveforms and sweep waveforms.

member.name: M:RohdeSchwarz.RsScope.RsScopeWaveform.ReadWaveform(Ivi.Driver.PrecisionTimeSpan,Ivi.Driver.IWaveform{System.SByte})
member.summary: This method initiates an acquisition on the channels that you enable with the Configure Channel function. It then waits for the acquisition to complete, and returns the waveform for the channel you specify. You call the FetchWaveform function to obtain the waveforms for each of the remaining enabled channels without initiating another acquisition. Identifier = RSSCOPE_FUNC_READ_WAVEFORM

member.name: M:RohdeSchwarz.RsScope.RsScopeWaveform.ReadWaveform(Ivi.Driver.PrecisionTimeSpan,Ivi.Driver.IWaveform{System.Double})

It then waits for the acquisition to complete, and returns the waveform for the channel you specify. This method initiates an acquisition on the channels that you enable with the
Configure channel method. It then waits for the acquisition to complete, obtains
a main waveform measurement on the channel you specify, and returns the
measurement value. You specify a particular measurement type, such as rise time,
frequency, and voltage peak-to-peak. You can call the FetchMainMeasurement
method separately for any other waveform measurement that you want to obtain on
a specific channel without initiating another acquisition.

Restricts the maximum number of frames to be calculated. Due to the other
parameter settings, the required number of frames may become very high, thus
slowing performance. By restricting the number of frames, you can avoid
performance loss without changing the other parameters.
Due to the restriction of the number of frames, the waveform may only be
analyzed partially. This attribute queries the percentage of the trace that was
analyzed, i.e. which part of the trace was included in the frame calculation.
Defines the minimum factor by which two neighboring frames overlap. If the
required number of frames to cover the input values allows for more overlap, the
The higher the overlap factor, the more frames are used. This leads to more
individual results and improves detection of transient signal effects. However,
it also extends the duration of the calculation.

Sets the width of the waveform mask in vertical direction. The specified number

pulled upwards, the lower half is pulled down, and the overall height of the
mask is twice the vertical width.

Set the number of time quanta before the sample point (T1Segment) and after the
sample point (T2Segment). T1Segment comprises the segments Synch_seg, Prop_seg,
and Phase_seg1 which are specified in the CAN standard. T2Segment matches

If disabled, only Y-values - mostly voltage values - are written.
Enables the export of raw sample data of the ADC, and sets the data format to
integer 8 bit. This format reduces the file size (1 Byte/sample instead of 4
Bytes/sample in binary files) but decreases the precision of the values.
Currently, the setting is not available for the export of digital channel data
and for the export of interleaved X/Y values.
Enables or disables the display update during an Nx SINGLE acquisition.
ON: Disables the display update for maximum export speed.
OFF: Enables the display update. The export is slower.
This method configures the zoom area to be used for limited data export. The
data included in the zoom area are saved, if at least one zoom is defined for
Includes or excludes the indicated channel in waveform export. The data of
Selects the histogram to be exported.
Sets the mode of exported data: relative or absolute frequency of amplitude
Stes the file name and path to save the histogram to.
Saves the waveform(s) to the file specified with
This method transfers the histogram data to the controlling computer.
This control selects the measurement to be exported.
Selects which result data you want to export, the long term Seasurement, or the
Stes the file name and path to save the long term data.
Saves the data to the file specified with RSSCOPE_ATTR_LONG_TERM_EXPORT_FILE
This method transfers the long term measurement data to the controlling
Selects the language to be used in the report. Available languages are listed in
Selects the paper size: A4 or US Letter.
Enter the user name that appears in the general information section at the
Enter a comment that appears in the general information section at the beginning
By default, the Rohde & Schwarz logo is shown in the header of the report
pages. You can switch the logo off, or select your logo to be shown.
Defines the logo file that is used on the report if
Sets the file name and path to save the report to. The file extension defines
the file format: PDF, HTML, or DOC.
Saves the report to the specified file.
If enabled, inserts the default prefix in the file name. The prefix indicates
the type of data that is saved, for example, Histogram, RefCurve, Settings.
User-defined text to be inserted after the prefix.
If enabled, inserts the specified user text after the prefix.
If enabled, inserts the current date.
If enabled, inserts the current time.
Defines the default path displayed in the file selection dialog box for loading
Resets the path for file operations to the default path.
Resets all autonaming settings to the default value, including the path.
Defines the file name when an image of the display is stored to a file rather
than printed to a printer using the HCOPy:IMMediate command.
Prints an image of the display to the printer or saves an image to a file or the
clipboard, depending on the RSSCOPE_ATTR_HARDCOPY_DEVICE_DESTINATION attribute.
The printer is defined by RSSCOPE_ATTR_HARDCOPY_SELECT_PRINTER attribute. The
file name for storage is defined by RSSCOPE_ATTR_HARDCOPY_FILE_NAME attribute.
This command queries the name of the first printer (in the list of printers)
If no printer is configured an empty string is output.
This command queries the name of the next printer installed under Windows. After
all available printer names have been output, an empty string enclosed by
quotation marks (') is output for the next query. Further queries are answered
The RSSCOPE_ATTR_HARDCOPY_GET_FIRST_PRINTER attribute should be sent previously
to return to the beginning of the printer list and query the name of the first
Defines the color mode for printing.
This command selects the printer output medium (Disk, Printer or Clipboard).
The type of instrument is selected with
default output medium. Therefore the HCOPy:DESTination command should always be
sent after setting the device type.
Defines the file format for the image of the display.
Inverts the background color. So you can print waveforms with normal waveform
Selects a configured printer. To determine which printers are installed, use the
Defines the default color set for printing of the display image.
Inverts the colors of the output, i.e. a dark waveform is printed on a white
